Award.AwardTitle: WSC-Category 3: Collaborative: The role of local water resources in the water sustainability of Los Angeles
Award.AbstractNarration:
Like many cities in semi-arid regions, Los Angeles relies on extensive, centralized redistribution projects for its water supply. Water is transported hundreds of kilometers to support agricultural and urban activities in southern California; however, allocations from remote sources have been declining due to drought, over-extractions, and competing water needs. Increasingly, local governments and water districts are relying on local water sources within the southern California coastal areas including local groundwater, rainwater capture, conservation measures, and recycled water sources. Yet, these resources are managed by a complex set of agencies and water districts with different structures, histories, and priorities, but which often access similar water resources. In addition, the jurisdictions of different water management institutions rarely correspond to watershed and other hydrologic boundaries, such that the connectivities of the socio-political system and the connectivities of the ecohydrologic system present a set of very complex networks for water management. This project will focus on understanding the coupled ecohydrologic and decision-making processes that determine the availability of local water resources in southern California, with the goal of addressing the questions 1) What is the current structure of local groundwater, wastewater, and stormwater management? 2) What are the ecohydrologic constraints on local groundwater and rainwater resources? 3) What is the regional water balance? 4) What are the overlaps and disconnects between the ecohydrologic and decision-making domains? 5) What are feasible targets for conservation given our understanding of biophysical, technological, political, and fiscal constraints? 6) How are these impacted by scenarios of future climate change? To address these issues, this project will draw on extensive existing datasets from previous research as well as public utility and agency data to: model the local water balance and groundwater flows; analyze the structure of local water management institutions; compare and contrast the ecohydrologic and political boundaries and constraints on local water resources; evaluate the vulnerabilities of the ecohydrologic and decision-making components of the local water system to climate, fiscal austerity and land use change; and utilize modeling and decision-making tools to evaluate proposed best practices.

This project addresses the most critical issues for water sustainability in the region, many of which involve decreasing southern California's reliance on imported water. To do this, the linkages and mismatches between the natural and human components of the water system must be analyzed. The project will directly evaluate the decision-making tools currently used by local agencies and NGOs to plan groundwater infiltration projects. It will also integrate research datasets with other public and published local information about water consumption and end uses, outdoor landscaping and species specific water use, and current information about best management practices (BMPs) for Los Angeles. These will be evaluated relative to institutional and political constraints such as resistance to maintaining existing infrastructure (due to costs) and funding new initiatives. There will be stakeholder involvement in direct meetings and in a publicly available data repository. Stakeholder partners will form a Technical Advisory Board to provide input on usable data products for local applications. In collaboration with students and a post-doctoral researcher, a central website for project datasets and results will be developed, and data services that are responsive to the needs of the Technical Advisory Board will be provided, including reports and synthetic analyses. The project will engage local students at the high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels as well as in K-12 teacher training activities at the participating institutions and outreach activities of local NGOs. Through a subcontract with the local grassroots organization Urban Semillas, the project will incorporate the results of the research into "Agua University," a program for underserved and minority high school students in Los Angeles. Finally, the project will partner with the non-profit organization TreePeople to enhance their outreach and education facility focused on water infiltration, conservation, and quality.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Like many cities in semi-arid regions, Los Angeles relies on extensive redistribution projects for water supply. Water is transported hundreds of kilometers to support urban activities in southern California and agriculture; however, allocations from remote sources have been declining due to drought, over-allocation, and competing water needs.  Increasingly, local governments and water districts are committing to increased reliance on local water sources including local groundwater, rainwater capture, conservation measures, and recycled water sources.  Yet, these resources are managed by a complex set of agencies and water districts with different structures, histories, and priorities. Urban ecohydrologic processes and water budgets in urbanized regions have been poorly parameterized and largely unexplored. This project focused on understanding the coupled ecohydrologic and decision-making processes that determine the availability of local water resources in southern California.

We used data from the LA Department of Water and Power (LADWP). Results showed that household income was the primary driver of water consumption across the city (Mini et al., 2014a,b; Hogue and Pincetl, 2015). We found that mandatory conservation restrictions are most effective at reducing water consumption for single family residential households. The greatest impact resulted from the combination of mandatory watering restrictions and a price increase, which led to a water consumption reduction of 23% in July/August 2009, while voluntary restrictions led to only a 6% reduction in water use [Mini et al., 2015].

Analysis of streamflow in the region showed that imported irrigation water has significantly altered the timing and volume of streamflow. The difference between summer streamflow before vs. during-conservation periods was enough to serve 160,000 customers in Los Angeles (Manago and Hogue, 2017).

 We synthesized all available data on the water use of urban trees and lawns in Los Angeles to test current modeling methods for estimating urban evapotranspiration (ET), an estimate of the irrigation requirements of urban landscapes. We found that during very dry Santa Ana wind conditions or at sites where lawns were extensively shaded, current lawn ET models are inaccurate (Litvak and Pataki 2016). For trees, the most common method of estimating watering requirements used by water managers is highly inaccurate due to large differences in water use behaviors of different urban tree species (Litvak et al. 2017b).  We developed alternative approaches to modeling evapotranspiration (ET) based on field observations and a mechanistic understanding of variations in plant water use. We then combined ET models with biodiversity surveys of the urban forest of Los Angeles, and remote sensing of tree and lawn cover to obtain the most robust estimates to date of municipal-scale landscape water use. The results showed that 70% of ET in Los Angeles is contributed by lawns (Litvak et al. 2017a). Irrigated urban trees require a smaller allocation of irrigation water than expected, suggesting that the urban tree canopy of Los Angeles can be maintained with fairly modest levels of irrigation.

To synthesize all of these datasets, we developed an integrated model, Artes, that can be used to develop strategies for water management in the region.  In so doing, we researched the historical evolution of this current water management system and the implications for adaptation to climate change. We used the model to determine whether Los Angeles has sufficient local water resources to completely cease water imports (Pincetl et al in prep), We also compared water prices under different scenarios, including complete water self-reliance through new water recycling, conservation in outdoor water use and new management for groundwater resources (Porse et al in prep).  Both of these analyses are made possible by the unique parameterization of Artes, which is a first of its kind regional, integrated water model (Porse et al 2017).  We find that Los Angeles will not go dry if groundwater is managed as a regional resource supplemented with limited imports to regenerate the basins in high rain years (approximately every 15 years).  This scenario is predicated on continued and increased water conservation, a shift in outdoor landscaping to climate appropriate trees and vegetation, and increased stormwater capture, none of which is infeasible.  Our analysis also suggests that this strategy will lead to more affordable water than continued reliance on imports.

            This project has been of great interest to local stakeholders, with extensive press coverage. We have developed several publicly accessible policy briefs, technical briefs, and fact sheets summarizing the results and the data are publicly available. The research team is further developing a regional summit to highlight the water self reliance findings, and the utility of the Artes modeling tool to regional water managers.  The intent is to institutionalize the use of Artes in decision making toward a more water self reliant region that can be resilient to unforeseen changes in precipitation in the future.  This could have only been accomplished through the integration of hydrologic science, ecology, institutional analysis and systems modeling.
